messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 55 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Hypercontractivity on HDX II: Symmetrization and 𝑞-Norms

Paper Abstract: Abstract Bourgain’s symmetrization theorem is a powerful technique reducing boolean analysis on product spaces to the cube. It states that for any product Ωi⊗dsuperscriptsubscriptΩ𝑖tensor-productabsent𝑑\Omega_{i}^{\otimes d}, function f:Ωi⊗d→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptsubscriptΩ𝑖tensor-productabsent𝑑ℝf:\Omega_{i}^{\otimes d}\to\mathbb{R}, and q>1𝑞1q>1: ∥T12​f​(x)∥q≤∥f~​(r,x)∥q≤∥Tcq​f​(x)∥qsubscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑇12𝑓𝑥𝑞subscriptdelimited-∥∥~𝑓𝑟𝑥𝑞subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑇subscript𝑐𝑞𝑓𝑥𝑞\left\lVert T_{\frac{1}{2}}f(x)\right\rVert_{q}\leq\left\lVert\tilde{f}(r,x)\right\rVert_{q}\leq\left\lVert T_{c_{q}}f(x)\right\rVert_{q} where Tρ​f=∑ρS​f=Ssubscript𝑇𝜌𝑓superscript𝜌𝑆superscript𝑓absent𝑆T_{\rho}f=\sum\limits\rho^{S}f^{=S} is the noise operator and f~​(r,x)=∑rS​f=S​(x)~𝑓𝑟𝑥subscript𝑟𝑆superscript𝑓absent𝑆𝑥\tilde{f}(r,x)=\sum\limits r_{S}f^{=S}(x) ‘symmetrizes’ f𝑓f by convolving its Fourier components {f=S}S⊆[d]subscriptsuperscript𝑓absent𝑆𝑆delimited-[]𝑑\{f^{=S}\}_{S\subseteq[d]} with a random boolean string r∈{±1}d𝑟superscriptplus-or-minus1𝑑r\in\{\pm 1\}^{d}. In this work, we extend the symmetrization theorem to high dimensional expanders (HDX). Adapting work of O’Donnell and Zhao (2021), we give as a corollary a proof of optimal global hypercontractivity for partite HDX, resolving one of the main open questions of Gur, Lifshitz, and Liu (STOC 2022). Adapting work of Bourgain (JAMS 1999), we also give the first booster theorem for HDX, resolving a main open questions of Bafna, Hopkins, Kaufman, and Lovett (STOC 2022). Our proof is based on two elementary new ideas in the theory of high dimensional expansion. First we introduce ‘q𝑞q-norm HDX’, generalizing standard spectral notions to higher moments, and observe every spectral HDX is a q𝑞q-norm HDX. Second, we introduce a simple method of coordinate-wise analysis on HDX which breaks high dimensional random walks into coordinate-wise components, and allows each component to be analyzed as a 111-dimensional operator locally within X𝑋X. This allows for application of standard tricks such as the replacement method, greatly simplifying prior analytic techniques.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 55 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 55"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "One clean qubit suffices for quantum communication advantage",
        "Entropic independence in high-dimensional expanders: Modified log-sobolev inequalities for fractionally log-concave polynomials and the ising model",
        "Approximating constraint satisfaction problems on high-dimensional expanders",
        "Spectral independence in high-dimensional expanders and applications to the hardcore model",
        "Sequential sweeps and high dimensional expansion",
        "Making the long code shorter",
        "High dimensional expanders: Eigenstripping, pseudorandomness, and unique games",
        "Hypercontractivity on high dimensional expanders",
        "The influence of variables in product spaces",
        "Small-set expansion in shortcode graph and the 2-to-2 conjecture",
        "Constant degree direct product testers with small soundness",
        "Quasi-linear size pcps with small soundness from hdx",
        "Étude des coefficients de fourier des fonctions de Lp(G)",
        "Walsh subspaces of lp-product spaces",
        "Localization schemes: A framework for proving mixing bounds for markov chains",
        "Rapid mixing for colorings via spectral independence",
        "Optimal mixing of glauber dynamics: Entropy factorization via high-dimensional expansion",
        "Agreement testing theorems on layered set systems",
        "Boolean function analysis on high-dimensional expanders",
        "Low acceptance agreement tests via bounded-degree symplectic hdxs",
        "Explicit sos lower bounds from high-dimensional expanders",
        "Chernoff bounds and reverse hypercontractivity on hdx",
        "High dimensional expanders imply agreement expanders",
        "Towards a proof of the 2-to-1 games conjecture?",
        "Exponentially small soundness for the direct product z-test",
        "An analogue of bonami’s lemma for functions on spaces of linear maps, and 2-2 games",
        "Polynomial bogolyubov for special linear groups via tensor rank",
        "Product mixing in compact lie groups",
        "Sharp thresholds of graph properties, and the k-sat problem",
        "Every monotone graph property has a sharp threshold",
        "Hypercontractivity on the symmetric group",
        "Boolean functions with low average sensitivity depend on few coordinates",
        "Eigenstripping, spectral decay, and edge-expansion on posets",
        "A structure theorem for boolean functions with small total influences",
        "Explicit lower bounds against ω𝜔\\omega (n)-rounds of sum-of-squares",
        "Lecture 13: Hypercontractivity and Small-Set Expansion",
        "Optimal mixing of the down-up walk on independent sets of a given size",
        "Some random series of functions",
        "The influence of variables on boolean functions",
        "Hypercontractivity for global functions and sharp thresholds",
        "Forbidden intersections for codes",
        "A prg for lipschitz functions of polynomials with applications to sparsest cut",
        "High dimensional combinatorial random walks and colorful expansion",
        "Local-to-global agreement expansion via the variance method",
        "Small set expansion in the johnson graph.",
        "Pseudorandom sets in grassmann graph have near-perfect expansion",
        "Construction of new local spectral high dimensional expanders",
        "Explicit constructions of ramanujan complexes of type ad",
        "Near optimal alphabet-soundness tradeoff pcps",
        "Analysis of boolean functions",
        "Local spectral expansion approach to high dimensional expanders part i: Descent of spectral gaps",
        "Sur les maxima des formes bilinéaires et sur les fonctionnelles linéaires",
        "On russo’s approximate zero-one law",
        "An extension of a convexity theorem due to m. riesz",
        "Generalizations and applications of hypercontractivity and small-set expansion"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 55 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Hypercontractivity on HDX II: Symmetrization and 𝑞-Norms, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
